title: How to Connect with Others With Food Allergies

content: Having an allergy can feel isolating at times. However, this doesn’t have to be the case! I’ve put together some of my top tips and advice for connecting with other people who have food allergies.

When I started blogging about my experiences, there was little content aimed at young people with food allergies. However, a lot has changed over the last few years. It’s been incredible to see people all over the world connect and flourish into a community that supports each other through thick and thin. Recently, I reached out to my community and asked them how they distinguish between panic attacks and anaphylaxis, and the response was overwhelming.
If you don’t know where to start when it comes to meeting people with allergies, keep reading!

It can be overwhelming when you first get diagnosed with a food allergy. Feeling that your life has changed forever and you will now be constantly on high alert is a lot to handle, especially if you feel you don't have anyone around you who understands. However, you are not alone, and I’m here to help!

content: I feel it’s particularly hard for people who are diagnosed with a food allergy later on in life. That’s because they experienced life before the allergy, and now there’s a whole new level of anxiety and a condition that they have to manage for the rest of their lives.
I’m always surprised at the number of people who reach out to me and say they are glad they came across my page as they thought they were the only ones who struggled with allergy anxiety.

Social media has its pros and cons, but it is a powerful tool. Being able to connect with people online all over the world has been so helpful. And learning from other people's experiences how they manage their food allergies is incredible!
It’s not just about learning from each other, but also about building friendships and being able to meet up, whether in person, on the phone, or online.

content: When I started posting on social media, there were only a handful of bloggers out there sharing the struggles and questions that people with food allergies tackle every day. It has been incredible to see this community grow over the last three years, with more people than ever sharing their experiences online.

sections.heading: Facebook vs. Instagram
content: Let’s start with support groups and Meetups on Facebook. This platform tends to have an older audience compared to Instagram. I feel Facebook is more geared toward parents who have children with food allergies. It's so important for them to find support, as they are responsible for managing their child's allergy until they are old enough to manage it for themselves.

There are loads of allergy Facebook groups to help them talk to other parents of children with food allergies, learn to manage the allergies better, and share their opinions. Usually, you have to send a request and a message about yourself to be let into these groups. Some of these groups have hundreds of thousands of people sharing their experiences!

I’ve found my own core audience by sharing my experiences on Instagram. I find this is where the community is most likely to share and comment on each other's posts and offer support. I’ve met so many people with food allergies through Instagram that I have come to see as close friends.

content: But you don’t have to run an allergy page to be part of this community. A lot of the content is from people who have stumbled into the Instagram community looking for some advice or someone going through the same things they are.

In the U.K., there is an allergy show every year called the Allergy and Free From Show. It's been an incredible experience to meet fellow allergy bloggers, but also the general public, at this show to share our experiences! There is also a range of allergy talks, which I’ve been lucky enough to be involved in to help others better manage their allergies. It's super fun, and a great experience that makes you feel proud and empowered.

sections.heading: Connecting With Professionals
content: It can sometimes be tricky to communicate with your allergist if you need information between appointments. However, there are sometimes opportunities to speak to them online or through their Instagram pages. While this can’t replace in-person appointments, it's nice knowing that you can speak to them should you need to. The same is true for others on your care team, like your dietitian and therapist.

content: Following these professionals’ social media pages is also a great learning tool. You can see their content for free and gain a better understanding of your allergies and the issues that can go along with them.
